questionContent.questionText:
1. Obstructing the passage of x-rays: radio[paque]

2. Permitting the passage of x-rays: radio[lucent]

3. Aids physicians in performing ultrasound procedures: [sono]grapher

4. Transformation of stable substances into charged particles: [ion]ization

5. Radioactive drug administered for diagnostic purposes: radio[pharmaceutical]

6. Radioactive chemical that gives off energy in the form of radiation: radio[isotope/nuclide]

7. A physician who specializes in diagnostic radiology: radi[ologist]

8. Study of the uses of radioactive substances in the diagnosis of disease: [nuclear] medicine

instructions.instructions: Complete the medical terms based on the deﬁnitions and word parts given.

readingPart.reading:
computed tomographymagnetic resonance imaging
contrast studiesultrasonography
interventional radiology

questionContent.questionText:
1. Radiopaque substances are given and conventional x-rays taken [contrast studies].

2. Use of echoes of high-frequency sound waves to diagnose disease [ultrasonography].

3. A magnetic ﬁeld and radio waves are used to form images of the body [magnetic resonance imaging].

4. X-ray pictures are taken circularly around an area of the body, and a computer synthesizes the information into composite images [computed tomography].

5. Therapeutic procedures are performed by a radiologist under the guidance of CT, MRI, or ultrasonography [interventional radiology ].

instructions.instructions: Match the special diagnostic techniques below with their deﬁnitions.

questionContent.questionText:
1. myelography [spinal cord]

2. retrograde pyelography [urinary tract]

3. angiography [blood vessels]

4. upper GI series [esophagus, stomach, and small intestine]

5. cholangiography [bile vessels (ducts)]

6. barium enema [lower gastrointestinal tract]

7. hysterosalpingography [uterus and fallopian tubes]

instructions.instructions: Match the diagnostic x-ray test with the part of the body that is imaged in the dropdown.

questionContent.questionText:
1. PA [posteroanterior view (back to front)]

2. supine [lying on the back]

3. prone [lying on the belly]

4. AP [anteroposterior view (front to back)]

5. lateral [on the side]

6. oblique [x-ray tube positioned on an angle]

7. lateral decubitus [lying down on the side]

8. adduction [movement toward the midline]

9. inversion [turned inward]

10. abduction [movement away from the midline]

11. recumbent [lying down; prone or supine]

12. eversion [turning outward]

13. ﬂexion [bending a part]

14. extension [straightening a limb]

instructions.instructions: Match the x-ray views or positions with their meanings in the dropdown.

readingPart.reading: process, test, or procedure in which something is measured or observed outside a living organism
process, test, or procedure in which something is measured or observed in a living organism
radioactive drug (radionuclide plus chemical) that is given for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes
tests in which radioactive substance (radioisotopes) are administered with chemicals and followed as they travel throughout the body
the rate of absorption of a radionuclide into an organ or tissue
imaging technique in which a radiopharmaceutical is injected intravenously and traced within the blood vessels of the lung scanned
imaging technique in which a radiopharmaceutical is inhaled and its passage through the respiratory tract is traced on a scan
imaging technique in which a radiopharmaceutical is given intravenously and taken up by bone tissue, followed by scanning to detect the amount of the radioactive substance in the bone
imaging technique in which a radioactive substance is given orally and a scan (image) is made to assess its uptake in the thyroid gland

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following medical terms.

readingPart.reading: machine that detects rays emitted by radioactive substances
radioactive glucose is injected and traced to body cells
a radioactive form (radionuclide) of a substance; gives off radiation
handheld device that sends and receives ultrasound signals
ultrasound is used to create an image of the heart
nuclear medicine imaging of the lymphatic system
nuclear medicine test to evaluate the function of the thyroid gland
combination of a PET scan and a CT scan to show both structure and function of the body

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms

questionContent.questionText:
1. -gram [record]

2. ultra- [beyond]

3. vitr/o [glass]

4. viv/o [life]

5. pharmaceut/o [drug]

6. son/o [sound]

7. therapeut/o [treatment ]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following word parts.

questionContent.questionText:
1. MRI [magnetic resonance imaging]
2. SPECT [single photon emission computed tomography]
3. PACS [picture archival and communications system]
4. UGI [upper gastrointestinal/upper gastrointestinal series/upper gastrointestinal]
5. CXR [chest x-ray]
6. DSA [digital subtraction angiography]
7. RP [retrograde pyelogram]
8. LAT [lateral]
9. U/S [ultrasound]
10. Tc-99m [radioactive technetium/technetium radiopharmaceutical]

1. X-ray examination of the kidney after injection of contrast
[retrograde pyelogram]
2. Diagnostic procedure frequently used to assess fetal size and development
[ultrasound]
3. X-ray examination of the esophagus, stomach, and intestines
[upper gastrointestinal (series)]
4. X-ray of blood vessels made by taking two images (with and without contrast) and subtracting the digitized data for one from the data for the other
[digital subtraction angiography]
5. Radioisotope used in nuclear medicine (tracer studies)
[radioactive technetium]
6. Radioactive substances and a computer used to create 3D images
[single photon emission computed tomography]
7. Diagnostic procedure produces magnetic resonance images of all three planes of the body and visualizes soft tissue throughout the body
[magnetic resonance imaging]
8. Replacement of traditional films with digital equivalents
[picture archival and communications system]
9. X-ray view from the side
[lateral]
10. Diagnostic procedure (x-rays are used) necessary to investigate thoracic disease
[chest x-ray]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the term that best matches the description.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Mr. Jones was scheduled for ultrasound-guided thoracentesis. He was sent to the [interventional radiology/radiation oncology/nuclear medicine] department for the procedure.

2. In order to better visualize Mr. Smith’s small intestine, Dr. Wong ordered a [SBFT/perfusion study/hysterosalpingography]. She hoped to determine why he was having abdominal pain and diarrhea.

3. After a head-on automobile collision, Sam was taken to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The paramedics suspected head trauma, and the doctors ordered an emergency [CT scan/PET scan/U*/S] of his head.  

4. In light of Sue’s symptoms of fever, cough, and malaise, the doctors thought that the consolidated, hazy [radiopaque/radioisotope/radiolucent] area on the chest x-ray represented a pneumonia. 

5. Fred, a lung cancer patient, experienced a seizure recently. His oncologist ordered a brain [MRI/ultrasound/pulmonary angiogram], which showed a tumor involving the left frontal lobe of the brain. Fred was treated with Gamma Knife irradiation, and the tumor decreased in size. He has had no further seizures.

6. Tom recently developed a cough and fever. A chest x-ray and [CT/myelogram/IVP] of the chest show that a [mediastinal/pelvic/spinal] mass is present. [Mediastinoscopy/Cystoscopy/Lumbar puncture] and biopsy of the mass reveal Hodgkin disease on histopathologic examination. He is treated with chemotherapy, and his symptoms disappear. A repeat x-ray shows that the mass has decreased remarkably, and a [PET/SPECT/MRI] scan shows no uptake of 18F-FDG in the chest, indicating that the mass is ﬁbrosis and not tumor.

7. Paola, a 50-year-old woman with diabetes, experiences chest pain during a stress test, and her [ECG/U*/S/EEG]  shows evidence of ischemia. A [radiopharmaceutical/contrast agent/transducer] called technetium Tc99m sestamibi (Cardiolite) is injected intravenously, and uptake is assessed with a [gamma camera/probe/CT scanner], which shows an area of poor perfusion in the left ventricle.

8. Sally has a routine pelvic examination, and her [gynecologist/neurologist/urologist] detects an irregular area of enlargement in the anterior wall of the uterus. A pelvic [U*/S study/angiogram/PET scan] is performed, which demonstrates the presence of ﬁbroids in the uterine wall. The examination involves placing a gel over her abdominopelvic area and applying a [ultrasound transducer/radionuclide/MRI scanner] to send/receive sound vibrations to/from the pelvic region.

9. Sally was having palpitations in the early evening. An ECG revealed possible left ventricular hypertrophy. Her physician ordered an [ECHO/EUS/UGI] to rule out valvular heart disease.  

10. Joe, a 75-year-old man with a long smoking history, noticed blood in his sputum. His primary care physician ordered a/an [chest CT/abdominal CT/ultrasound of his heart] for further evaluation.

instructions.instructions: Select the correct terms to complete the sentences.
